contentrichtext.text: The '''I. G. Baker Company''' was a mercantile and grocery company based in [[Fort Benton, Montana]], started by Isaac Gilbert Baker and his brother, George Amos Baker, as I. G. Baker & Brother in 1866.<ref name="k1">Klassen, Henry Cornelius. ''Eye on the future: business people in Calgary and the Bow Valley, 1870-1900''. Calgary: Univ. Alberta Press, 2002." Ch 2 is about the Conrads & I. G. Baker & Co., but ch. 1 & 3 are also pertinent.</ref> After the Conrad brothers (Charles E. & Wm. G.) were admitted as partners in 1873, the company name was changed to I. G. Baker & Co., which name was retained after the Conrads purchased George Bakerâ€™s interest in 1874.<ref name="k1" /> In 1891, the Canadian assets of the company were purchased by its chief rival there, the [[Hudson's Bay Company]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hbc.com/hbcheritage/history/places/stores/calgary.asp|title=HBC Heritage - Our History - Places: Calgary|work=[[Hudson's Bay Company]]|accessdate=2009-05-17|quote=In 1891 the Company bought out the Canadian assets of I.G. Baker}}</ref> The company was prominent in early Western Canadian history. It operated the first store established in [[Calgary, Alberta]] in 1875.<ref>{{cite book|last=Foran|first=Max|title=Calgary, Canada's frontier metropolis : an illustrated history|year=1982|publisher=Windsor Publications|isbn=0-89781-055-4|page=40|url=http://www.ourfutureourpast.ca/loc_hist/page.aspx?id=3610330}}</ref> There were also stores in [[Fort Macleod, Alberta|Fort Macleod]] and [[Lethbridge, Alberta|Lethbridge]], [[Alberta]] and in [[Fort Walsh, Saskatchewan]]. The I. G. Baker Company brought a herd of cattle from Montana to southern [[Alberta]], the first livestock imported for what is now a significant industry in Alberta. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Fur trade]] [[Category:Economic history of Canada]]
